title: 109_s3889
content: The Act titled "Gulf Coast Housing Accessibility Act of 2006" includes provisions for project-based vouchers. The Gulf Coast Housing Accessibility Act of 2006 provides additional assistance for project-based housing vouchers to support affordable housing in areas affected by Hurricane Katrina, Rita, or Wilma of 2005, including repairing or rebuilding damaged housing and supporting new housing structures. The Gulf Coast Housing Accessibility Act of 2006 provides funds for 4,500 project-based vouchers to support affordable housing in areas affected by Hurricane Katrina, Rita, or Wilma. The vouchers are for housing units for persons with disabilities, elderly families, and individuals and families who were homeless prior to the disaster. The Homeless Assistance Act defines "homeless" to include adults who are homeless. The Secretary awards project-based vouchers to a State agency designated by the Governor, or a local housing agency if the State agency is unable to request funds. The Secretary can transfer administration of vouchers to local housing agencies for specific developments. Project-based vouchers are exempt from certain limitations. $200,000,000 is authorized for project-based assistance under section 8(o)(13) of the United States Housing Act of 1937. The funds are authorized to ensure that 25% of units created under the low-income housing tax credit are affordable to very low-income individuals. The section becomes effective upon appropriation of necessary funds. The Attorney General will collect a user fee for commercial explosive materials. FEMA housing assistance is addressed in Section 3. Amendments to the Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act include adding "semipermanent, and permanent" to the types of housing covered under Section 408(c)(1). Conditions for providing temporary housing assistance are also outlined. The President must consider cost efficiency and likelihood of occupancy when deciding on temporary, semipermanent, or permanent housing options under Section 408(c)(1) of the Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. The President must consider cost efficiency, likelihood of occupancy, and other conditions deemed necessary when providing housing assistance longer than 3 to 6 months to restore permanent housing stock lost due to a disaster. When providing housing assistance after a disaster, the President must consider cost efficiency and the needs of predisaster renters, especially low-income households. The housing units deployed after a disaster must consider minimizing poverty concentration, ensuring accessibility for persons with disabilities, and placement within a community. The housing units deployed after a disaster will be placed within a reasonable distance from essential services like transportation, employment opportunities, healthcare facilities, schools, day care services, and financial and employment counseling. This applies to individuals and households affected by a disaster occurring on or after the enactment of this Act. The Act applies to individuals and households affected by disasters occurring after its enactment, including Hurricanes Katrina, Rita, and Wilma of 2005. SEC. 4. TRANSFER OF TEMPORARY RENTAL ASSISTANCE. The Director of FEMA will transfer funds to the Disaster Voucher Program at HUD to implement the program for individuals and households in need of assistance. This includes those in FEMA's transitional housing program and rental assistance programs. FEMA will work with State and local governments and private entities to provide notice and assistance to individuals and households during the transfer process. Recipients of FEMA housing assistance can choose to opt-out of being transferred to the Disaster Voucher Program. This section applies to individuals and households affected by disasters. Individuals and households affected by disasters occurring after the enactment of this Act, including Hurricanes Katrina, Rita, and Wilma of 2005.
